content.description:
Win, Lose, No Draws is a deceptive-looking route of sustained difficulty, punctuated by a number of rests.  Straight off the deck pull strenuous moves to obtain a corner system rest.  Ascend a brief arete by edging and then probe for purchase on slopers.  Traverse over the anchors of The Little King  on a large ledge.  Regroup and then battle to the chains using sidepulls and pockets.  This one isn't over until you've clipped the chains. 

  I personally enjoyed this route much more than I was expecting.  The movement was varied and challenging; the rock was seemingly solid.  Is it better than nearby routes of comparable difficulty?  I'm not sure.  Is it worth climbing at some point?  Definitely.
content.protection: Approximately 12 bolts to leaver biners.  There is a chain draw midway to aid in cleaning.
content.location: Win, Lose, No Draws is on the far left side of the King formation.  It is the second route from the left.  The Little King is to the left; Kings Arete is to the right.

content.description: Really an under appreciated classic. This thing is as fun as 50 ft can be. The exposure off the flake is awesome. Your like 150 ft up at the second bolt. Great holds. Great movement. Steep. Sweet 12-  dont skip this one
content.location: Across the draw bridge. Belay off the big flake ledge.  Shares three bolts with kings crystal then trends right

content.description: Very short but enjoyable route on the far left side of King.  Starts with a short boulder problem to a good rest, then climbs through some easier blocky terrain to a surprisingly tough, slopey crux at the top.  Probably only 1-1.5 stars, but it's definitely worth a go!
content.protection: Bolts, chains.  'Biners available for lowering at the top.
content.location: On the far left side of King, left of "Win, Loose, No Draws" and 2 climbs left of the striking "Kings Arete".  It's the really short one.

content.description: What a stellar line!  Great position, exposure, and fun moves up the green lichened arete of the King formation.  The minimal hassle of a short approach pitch might deter some climbers, but it is totally worth it.
content.protection: 5 bolts + anchors - 5.11- approach pitch to ledge   8 bolts + anchors
content.location: Pretty easy to find this by just looking up and finding the striking green arete on the left side of the King formation.  Climb the approach pitch to a set of anchors on a sizable ledge.  The climb is straight up the arete from the ledge.

climbs.name: King's Ransom
climbs.fa: Jim Scott, Eric Fazio-Rhicard & John Hayes (2005)

content.description:
Tricky face and seam climbing leads past two tightly spaced bolts.  Follow jugs up dubious looking rock to obtain a glorious pocket.  A challenging rightward traverse leads to a less-than-vertical, near-slab finish. 

King's Ransom is a mid-tier route with varied gym-like movement.  The slab finish is unlike anything at the Chessman area.  Unfortunately the short section of questionable rock slightly sours the experience.
content.location: King's Ransom is located on the King formation.  To the left is the mixed route King's Ransom; to the right is the sport route The Fool's Gambit.  It is the leftmost of four densely packed sport routes.

content.description: Follow Serfs Up's first three bolts then break left to clip the next bolt. Follow powerful and fun, bouldery moves to a ledge, then a fun sequence through the final two bolts to the leaver-biner anchor. Worth doing if you're up there on the ledge.The book says to continue straight up via thin holds, but you will probably do what we did and go a bit right and then back left since straight up seemed very hard for the grade and perhaps a hold or two had broken off since the FA.
content.location: Left line off Serfs Up ledge

content.description: A route worth doing at the King. Name comes from a brief but fun wide section not normally found on sport routes.
content.location: On the King formation, between Fool's Gambit and Queen of Kings.

content.description: Shallow right-facing dihedral. Fun, wandering, technical climbing.
content.location: On the right side of the "King" formation, third sport route from climber's right.

content.description: Steep to start then thin moves to the bottom of a big flake.  Then a final interesting finish.
content.location: Work along the base of the cliffs until you have to hike uphill around a low angle moderate looking arete that is close to 100 feet tall. When you are roughly even with the top contour over to the top of this.  From this notch drop down and follow the ledge over to the "rampart".  Climb starts up overhanging flake at the back of the ledge where it is scooped out.  Follow bolts right and up.

content.description: A really fun mixed route on the King formation. Start in corner with bolt, plug a few pieces, and move right to left-facing corner. Jam (!) through the crux on good gear and pull out roof via satisfying laybacks. Some face climbing past 2 bolts puts you at the anchor.
content.protection: A few bolts, and a set of stoppers and doubles of cams from fingers to #2 BD and a single #3 BD will get you up with gear to spare.
content.location: On the King, 2 routes left of Fool's Gambit. Starts in a right-facing corner.

content.description:
Thirteen traditional and sport lines ranging from 5.9- to 5.12+.  Serf's Up (5.12-) on the Rampart and Kings Arete are classic.  This area includes the King's Rampart sector. 

  The King sector sees the most shade of any wall in the area.  Sun starts hitting the wall around 3pm.
